titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Collins Land Company (Helena, Mont.) Records 1898-1951
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Jodi Allison-Bunnell and Jack Rowan
titlestmt.sponsor: Funding for creating this finding aid was provided through a grant awarded by the National Historic Publications and Records Commission. Funding for encoding this finding aid was provided through a grant awarded by the National Endowment for the Humanities.

publicationstmt.publisher: Maureen and Mike Mansfield Library, The University of Montana--Missoula

profiledesc.creation: Finding aid encoded by Jodi Allison-Bunnell and Jack Rowan (2004) and ArchProteus (2006)

repository.corpname: University of Montana, Mansfield Library, Archives and Special Collections

did.unittitle: Collins Land Company Records
did.abstract: This collection contains correspondence, financial, legal, promotional, and organizational records generated by the Collins Land Company as well as government publications regarding federal public lands and business records from three other Collins family enterprises. The Collins Land Company was based in Helena, Montana, and bought and sold public lands.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p:
Jeremiah Collins was born in Ireland in 1850 and came to America as a child. Orphaned at age twelve, he worked his way through public schools and Indiana State University in Terre Haute, from which he graduated in 1873. He went into journalism, working first for the Wabash News, then the Logansport Courier. He married Letta E. Fitzgerald in 1878; together, they went to Fort Benton, Montana Territory. In Fort Benton, he established the
River Press, which he edited until 1887. He also established the Great Falls Tribune in 1885. In 1889, he withdrew from newspapering to write a history of Montana. After completing that project, he was appointed receiver of public money in the United States General Land Office.

In 1889, Collins established the Collins Land Company in Helena, Montana. The company dealt with public lands, and bought and sold land scrip and represented clients to the Department of the Interior with regard to public lands. This company was so successful that he opened an eastern branch office in Washington, DC, in 1901. The Collins Land Company was one of the largest land scrip dealers in the United States and continued in the business until 1957, when Congress discontinued the use of scrip.
Collins had two children: Lena Agnes and Ted E. He died in 1934 in Washington.

Ted E. Collins took over the Land Company after his father's death and operated it until his death in 1956. The company had expanded into the insurance business in 1910, and that portion of the business increased steadily as the land scrip business declined.
Margaret Chivers was president of the company when its corporate charter expired in 1974 and it ceased to conduct business.

The Collins Realty Company was incorporated in Helena in 1909. Its charter expired in 1929. The Collins Company was incorporated in 1906, and its charter expired in 1926. The Beartooth Stock Company was a livestock raising and agricultural development business headquartered in Helena, Montana.

scopecontent.p: This collection contains correspondence, financial, legal, promotional, and organizational records generated by the Collins Land Company as well as government publications regarding federal public lands and business records from three other Collins family enterprises. The Collins Land Company was based in Helena, Montana, and bought and sold public lands. Materials in this collection provide particular insights into the history, procedures, and economy of public land management and sale during the first half of the twentieth century.

arrangement.p: The collection is divided into eight series:
Series II: Case Files, 28.5 linear feet, 1907-1951
Series III: Legal and Financial, 1.5 linear feet adn 2 oversize volumes, 1900-1921
Series IV: Printed Materials, 1.0 linear foot, 1899-1951
Series VI: Collins Realty Company, 0.5 linear feet, and 1 oversize volume, 1909-1920
Series VII: Collins Company, 0.25 linear feet, 1906-1920
Series VIII: Beartooth Stock Company, 0.25 linear feet, 1912-1939

accessrestrict.p: Researchers must use collection in accordance with the policies of Archives and Special Collections, the Maureen and Mike Mansfield Library, and The University of Montana--Missoula.

userestrict.p: Researchers are responsible for using in accordance with 17 U.S.C. and any other applicable statutes. Copyright transferred to The University of Montana

prefercite.p: [Name of document], Collins Land Company Records, Archives and Special Collections, Maureen and Mike Mansfield Library, The University of Montana--Missoula.

custodhist.p: The materials were largely in the possession of the Collins Land Company until time of donation.

acqinfo.p: Gift of Margaret Chivers, 1974; gift of Gary Williams, 1979; transferred from the Montana Historical Society, 1979.

processinfo.p: During original processing, it appears that the order of the materials was maintained. During 2004 reprocessing, series and subseries were designated and collection materials were significantly re-described.

controlaccess.p: This collection is indexed under the following headings in the online catalog. Researchers desiring materials about related topics, persons, or places should search the catalog using these headings.

did.unittitle: Correspondence

scopecontent.p: This series contains incoming, outgoing, interoffice and general correspondence generated and collected by the Collins Land Company detailing business projects, proposals, and practices spanning the first four decades of company operation. Series materials are almost exclusively exchanges with clients, potential buyers, and Federal land management officials. These records provide insights into the procedures and economy of public land sales during the first half of the 20th Century.

Case Files

scopecontent.p: This series contains land scrip case histories collected by the Collins Land Company as documentation for title purchases and transfers. The Collins Land Company created four distinct sequences for these case histories and attached a case number to each file (beginning at zero for each sequence). The original sequences and case numbers have been retained for historical reference; however, records explaining the tracking system rationale and detailing gaps in each sequence no longer existed at the time the collection was accessioned to the archives. These records provide early property definitions and ownership histories for land parcels across the United States, with particular emphasis on Montana and the Pacific Northwest.

Legal and Financial

scopecontent.p: This series contains one folder of financial records, 10 bound financial volumes, and one folder of legal documents generated by the Collins Land Company, including two volumes tracking account activity for land scrips allotted to Union Civil War veterans and soldiers who fought in the Spanish-American War. Legal documents include property deeds, prospecting patents, and court transcripts.

Printed Materials

scopecontent.p: This series contains Collins Land Company publications and advertisements as well as an extensive sequence of Federal government publications relating to management and dissolution of public lands. These government publications include Congressional legislation and U.S. Department of the Interior regulations.

scopecontent.p: This series consists of one bound volume containing the Collins Land Company's corporate bylaws and stockholder meeting minutes.

Collins Realty Company

scopecontent.p: This series contains four bound volumes of financial journals generated by the Collins Realty Company, a real estate development business headquartered in Helena, Montana.

Collins Company

scopecontent.p: This series contains a daily transaction ledger generated by the Collins Company, a holding company for Collins family business interests and located in Helena, Montana.

Beartooth Stock Company

scopecontent.p: This series consists of one bound volume containing the Beartooth Stock Company's articles of incorporation and stockholder meeting minutes. The company was a livestock raising and agricultural development business headquartered in Helena, Montana.
